newsitem.title: USA: Poll says Clinton has 61 percent approval rating.
newsitem.headline: Poll says Clinton has 61 percent approval rating.

text.p: Sixty-one percent of Americans approve of the way President Clinton is handling his job, according to a Time Magazine/CNN poll released Saturday.
Thirty percent of Americans disapprove of the president's performance, his lowest disapproval rating since March 1993.
The survey gave Clinton a 14-point lead over Republican presidential nominee Bob Dole among likely voters, 52 to 38 percent, with six percent backing billionare third-party candidate Ross Perot.
No presidential candidate who has trailed after the Labour Day holiday has come back to win except for incumbent Democrat Harry Truman in 1948.

In a sign Clinton's high approval rating could help fellow Democrats, 49 percent of likely voters said they would be more likely to cast a ballot for a congressional candidate who supported the president's policies, while 40 percent said they would be less likely.
If congressional elections were held today, 48 percent polled said they would vote for a Democrat while 44 percent said they would back a Republican.
The Time/CNN poll surveyed 2,080 Americans between Sept. 4-5 and had a sampling error of 2.2 percent.
Another poll released Saturday found 49 percent of voters said Clinton does a better job addressing the concerns of parents raising children while 31 percent favoured Dole.
The poll by U.S. News & World Report said there was a "Mommy and Daddy gap" with mothers twice as likely as fathers to view Clinton as better able to speak to parental concerns.
It said Clinton is supported for re-election by 52 percent of voters, while Dole is backed by 35 percent and the Reform Party's Perot by six percent.
The U.S. News survey of 1,000 registered voters was done between Sept. 3-4 and has a margin of error of 3.1 percent.
